
===============================================
TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:27:55.977861
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "How does Caesar first enter the play?",
    "answer": "Caesar first enters the play in Act 1, Scene 2, with a procession, accompanied by Antony, Calphurnia, Portia, Decius, Cicero, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, a Soothsayer, and others, including Marullus and Flavius and Commoners, as he is about to run a course, likely a triumphal procession, and is warned by a Soothsayer to \"Beware the Ides of March\"."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Caesar first enters the play in Act 1, Scene 2.",
    "Caesar enters the play with a procession.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Antony.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Calphurnia.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Portia.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Decius.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Cicero.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Brutus.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Cassius.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Casca.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by a Soothsayer.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by others.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Marullus.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Flavius.",
    "Caesar is accompanied by Commoners.",
    "Caesar is about to run a course.",
    "Caesar is running a likely triumphal procession.",
    "A Soothsayer warns Caesar to Beware the Ides of March."
  ]
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:27:58.339974
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

SC. 1\nFLAVIUS\nAll the Commoners exit. MARULLUS\nFLAVIUS\nThey exit in different directions. To hear the replication of your sounds\n Made in her concave shores? And do you now put on your best attire? And do you now cull out a holiday? And do you now strew flowers in his way\n That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood? Be gone!\n13\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 2\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nSennet. PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

input: {
    "question": "What does the Soothsayer say to Caesar?",
    "answer": "The Soothsayer says to Caesar: \"Beware the Ides of March.\""
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "The Soothsayer says something to Caesar.",
    "The Soothsayer's statement to Caesar is \"Beware the Ides of March.\""
  ]
}

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

input: {
    "context": "CAESAR\nSOOTHSAYER\nARTEMIDORUS\nDECIUS\nARTEMIDORUS\nCAESAR\nARTEMIDORUS\nCAESAR\nPUBLIUS\nCASSIUS\nCaesar goes forward, the rest following. Flourish. Enter Caesar, Antony, Lepidus; Brutus, Cassius,\nCasca, Decius, Metellus, Trebonius, Cinna; Publius,\nPopilius,  Artemidorus, the Soothsayer, and other\nSenators and Petitioners. The ides of March are come. Ay, Caesar, but not gone. Hail, Caesar. Read this schedule. Trebonius doth desire you to o’erread,\n At your best leisure, this his humble suit. O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit\n That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar. What touches us ourself shall be last served. Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly. What, is the fellow mad?\n13\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 2\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nSennet. SOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nSOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nEnter Caesar, Antony for the course, Calphurnia, Portia,\nDecius, Cicero, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, a Soothsayer;\nafter them Marullus and Flavius and Commoners. Calphurnia. Peace, ho! Caesar speaks. Calphurnia. Here, my lord. Stand you directly in Antonius’ way\n When he doth run his course.—Antonius. Caesar, my lord. Forget not in your speed, Antonius,\n To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say\n The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,\n Shake off their sterile curse. I shall remember. When Caesar says “Do this,” it is performed. Set on and leave no ceremony out. Caesar.\n115\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 2\nANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nThey exit with Caesar’s body. PLEBEIANS\nBRUTUS\n And bid me say to you by word of mouth—\n O Caesar! Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for  mine eyes,\n Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,\n Began to water. Is thy master coming? He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. Post back with speed and tell him what hath\n chanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,\n No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;\n Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse\n Into the marketplace. There shall I try,\n In my oration, how the people take\n The cruel issue of these bloody men,\n According to the which thou shalt discourse\n To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians. We will be satisfied!",
    "statements": [
        "The Soothsayer says something to Caesar.",
        "The Soothsayer's statement to Caesar is \"Beware the Ides of March.\""
    ]
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
"statements": [
{
"statement": "The Soothsayer says something to Caesar.",
"reason": "The context explicitly mentions the Soothsayer speaking to Caesar, so it can be directly inferred that the Soothsayer says something to Caesar.",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "The Soothsayer's statement to Caesar is \"Beware the Ides of March.\"",
"reason": "Although the Soothsayer does speak to Caesar, the specific statement \"Beware the Ides of March\" is not mentioned in the context. Therefore, it cannot be directly inferred that the Soothsayer's statement to Caesar is \"Beware the Ides of March.\"",
"verdict": 0
}

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "155\nJulius Caesar\nACT 4. SC. 3\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\n Which I respect not. I did send to you\n For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,\n For I can raise no money by vile means. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart\n And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring\n From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash\n By any indirection. I did send\n To you for gold to pay my legions,\n Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius? Should I have answered Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous\n To lock such rascal counters from his friends,\n Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;\n Dash him to pieces! I denied you not.\n149\nJulius Caesar\nACT 4. SC. 3\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus and Cassius exit. CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\n Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away. Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,\n And I will give you audience. Pindarus,\n Bid our commanders lead their charges off\n A little from this ground. Lucius,  do you the like, and let no man\n Come to our tent till we have done our conference. Let Lucilius  and Titinius guard our door. That you have wronged me doth appear in this:\n You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella\n For taking bribes here of the Sardians,\n Wherein my letters, praying on his side\n Because I knew the man, was slighted off. You wronged yourself to write in such a case.\n65\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nMETELLUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus exit. But when I tell him he hates flatterers,\n He says he does, being then most flatterèd. Let me work,\n For I can give his humor the true bent,\n And I will bring him to the Capitol. Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him. By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost? Be that the uttermost, and fail not then. Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,\n Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder none of you have thought of him. Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him. The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you,\n Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember\n What you have said, and show yourselves true\n Romans. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes,\n But bear it, as our Roman actors do,\n With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one.",

{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science.     ]

        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",

            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]

I did send to you\n For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,\n For I can raise no money by vile means. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart\n And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring\n From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash\n By any indirection. DECIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nCAESAR\nMETELLUS\n, to Cassius\n \n I wish your enterprise today may thrive. What enterprise, Popilius? Fare you well. What said Popilius Lena? He wished today our enterprise might thrive. I fear our purpose is discoverèd. Look how he makes to Caesar. Mark him. Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.—\n Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,\n Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,\n For I will slay myself. Cassius, be constant. Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes,\n For look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change. Trebonius knows his time, for look you, Brutus,\n He draws Mark Antony out of the way. Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go\n And presently prefer his suit to Caesar. He is addressed.\n83\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\n What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\n Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\n Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy\n As that same ague which hath made you lean.—\n What is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\n Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\n109\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\n Either a coward or a flatterer.—\n That I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\n Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\n To see thy Antony making his peace,\n Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\n Most noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\n Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\n It would become me better than to close\n In terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\n hart,\n Here didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\n Signed in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\n And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\n Dost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\n  \n Pardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\n Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\n Or shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\n Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\n Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\n Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.",

input: {
    "context": "Now I change my mind\n And partly credit things that do presage. Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign\n Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched,\n Gorging and feeding from our soldiers’ hands,\n Who to Philippi here consorted us. This morning are they fled away and gone,\n And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites\n Fly o’er our heads and downward look on us\n As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem\n A canopy most fatal, under which\n Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost. Believe not so.\nGo to the gate; somebody knocks. Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,\n I have not slept. Between the acting of a dreadful thing\n And the first motion, all the interim is\n Like a phantasma or a hideous dream.\n39\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 3\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\n \n But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens? It is the part of men to fear and tremble\n When the most mighty gods by tokens send\n Such dreadful heralds to astonish us. You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life\n That should be in a Roman you do want,\n Or else you use not. You look pale, and gaze,\n And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder,\n To see the strange impatience of the heavens. But if you would consider the true cause\n Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,\n Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,\n Why old men, fools, and children calculate,\n Why all these things change from their ordinance,\n Their natures, and preformèd faculties,\n To monstrous quality—why, you shall find\n That heaven hath infused them with these spirits\n To make them instruments of fear and warning\n Unto some monstrous state. Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man\n Most like this dreadful night,\n That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars\n As doth the lion in the Capitol;\n A man no mightier than thyself or me\n In personal action, yet prodigious grown,\n And fearful, as these strange eruptions are. ’Tis Caesar that you mean, is it not, Cassius? Let it be who it is. For Romans now\n Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors. But, woe the while, our fathers’ minds are dead,\n And we are governed with our mothers’ spirits.",

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

Cassius also uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.\n\nAdditionally, Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy. Cassius suggests that by joining the conspiracy, Brutus will be able to avenge Ligarius and restore honor to Rome.\n\nIt is likely that a combination of these factors, along with Cassius' persistent persuasion and manipulation, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators. However, the exact moment of Brutus' decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text."
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:28:12.841502
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "183\nJulius Caesar\nACT 5. SC. 1\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nHe draws. BRUTUS\nOCTAVIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\n For you have stolen their buzzing, Antony,\n And very wisely threat before you sting. Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers\n Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar. You showed your teeth  like apes and fawned like\n hounds\n And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,\n Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind\n Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers! Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today\n If Cassius might have ruled. Come, come, the cause.\n199\nJulius Caesar\nACT 5. SC. 4\nThey exit. BRUTUS\nBrutus, Messala, and Flavius exit. CATO\nLUCILIUS\nCato is killed. It is impossible that ever Rome\n Should breed thy fellow.—Friends, I owe more\n tears\n To this dead man than you shall see me pay.—\n I shall find time, Cassius; I shall find time.—\n Come, therefore, and to Thasos  send his body. His funerals shall not be in our camp,\n Lest it discomfort us.—Lucilius, come.—\n And come, young Cato. Let us to the field.—\n Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on. ’Tis three o’clock, and, Romans, yet ere night\n We shall try fortune in a second fight. Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, Cato, Lucilius, and\nFlavius. Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!\n65\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nMETELLUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus exit. But when I tell him he hates flatterers,\n He says he does, being then most flatterèd. Let me work,\n For I can give his humor the true bent,\n And I will bring him to the Capitol. Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him. By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost? Be that the uttermost, and fail not then. Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,\n Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder none of you have thought of him. Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him. The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you,\n Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember\n What you have said, and show yourselves true\n Romans. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes,\n But bear it, as our Roman actors do,\n With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one.",

Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy. However, it does not explicitly state what finally convinces Brutus.

2. Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy.
Verdict: 1
Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy.

3. Cassius appeals to Brutus' sense of justice and his dislike of flatterers, suggesting that Caesar is a tyrant who is being flattered and manipulated by others.
Verdict: 1
Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius appeals to Brutus' sense of justice and his dislike of flatterers, suggesting that Caesar is a tyrant who is being flattered and manipulated by others.

4. Cassius uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.
Verdict: 1
Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.

5. Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy.

Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy.

Verdict: 1
Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius suggests that by joining the conspiracy, Brutus will be able to avenge Ligarius and restore honor to Rome.

7. A combination of Cassius' persuasion and manipulation, along with other factors, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators.
Verdict: 1
Reason: The text explicitly states that Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy. Therefore, it can be inferred that a combination of Cassius' persuasion and manipulation, along with other factors, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators.

Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him. The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you,\\n Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember\\n What you have said, and show yourselves true\\n Romans. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes,\\n But bear it, as our Roman actors do,\\n With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one.\",\n    \"statements\": [\n        \"The text provided does not explicitly state what finally convinces Brutus to join the conspirators.\",\n        \"Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy.\",\n        \"Cassius appeals to Brutus' sense of justice and his dislike of flatterers, suggesting that Caesar is a tyrant who is being flattered and manipulated by others.\",\n        \"Cassius uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.\",\n        \"Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy.\",\n        \"Cassius suggests that by joining the conspiracy, Brutus will be able to avenge Ligarius and restore honor to Rome.\",\n        \"A combination of Cassius' persuasion and manipulation, along with other factors, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators.\",\n        \"The exact moment of Brutus' decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text.\"\n    ]\n}\nOutput: "

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:28:46.754879
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "Why does Calpurnia urge Caesar to stay home rather than appear at the Senate?",
    "answer": "Calpurnia urges Caesar to stay home because of her fear, which is hinted to be due to a bad dream or omen she had, suggesting that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate. She asks him to call it her fear that keeps him in the house, rather than his own decision, and even offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well, in order to avoid him having to go."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Calpurnia urges Caesar to stay home.",
    "Calpurnia's fear is the reason she urges Caesar to stay home.",
    "Calpurnia's fear is due to a bad dream or omen she had.",
    "Calpurnia's fear suggests that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate.",
    "Calpurnia asks Caesar to stay home due to her fear.",
    "Calpurnia does not want Caesar to make his own decision to go to the Senate.",
    "Calpurnia offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well.",
    "Calpurnia's offer is to avoid Caesar having to go to the Senate."
  ]
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:28:48.412902
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "79\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nShe kneels. CAESAR\nHe lifts her up. DECIUS\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nDECIUS\nCAESAR\n Do not go forth today. Call it my fear\n That keeps you in the house, and not your own. We’ll send Mark Antony to the Senate House,\n And he shall say you are not well today. Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this. Mark Antony shall say I am not well,\n And for thy humor I will stay at home. Enter Decius. Here’s Decius Brutus; he shall tell them so. Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar. I come to fetch you to the Senate House. And you are come in very happy time\n To bear my greeting to the Senators\n And tell them that I will not come today. Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser. I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius. Say he is sick. Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far,\n To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth? Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come. Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,\n Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so. The cause is in my will.\n13\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 2\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nSennet. Calphurnia. Peace, ho! Caesar speaks. Calphurnia. Here, my lord. Stand you directly in Antonius’ way\n When he doth run his course.—Antonius. Caesar, my lord. Forget not in your speed, Antonius,\n To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say\n The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,\n Shake off their sterile curse. I shall remember. When Caesar says “Do this,” it is performed. Set on and leave no ceremony out. Caesar.\n85\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 4\nARTEMIDORUS\n Thy lover,\n Artemidorus\nHe exits. PORTIA\nLUCIUS\nPORTIA\nEnter Artemidorus reading a paper. Caesar, beware of Brutus, take heed of\n Cassius, come not near Casca, have an eye to Cinna,\n trust not Trebonius, mark well Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged\n Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these\n men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou beest not\n immortal, look about you. Security gives way to\n conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee! Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,\n And as a suitor will I give him this. My heart laments that virtue cannot live\n Out of the teeth of emulation. If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live;\n If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive. Enter Portia and Lucius. I prithee, boy, run to the Senate House.",
    "statements": [
        "Calpurnia urges Caesar to stay home.",
        "Calpurnia's fear is the reason she urges Caesar to stay home.",
        "Calpurnia's fear is due to a bad dream or omen she had.",
        "Calpurnia's fear suggests that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate.",
        "Calpurnia asks Caesar to stay home due to her fear.",
        "Calpurnia does not want Caesar to make his own decision to go to the Senate.",
        "Calpurnia offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well.",
        "Calpurnia's offer is to avoid Caesar having to go to the Senate."
    ]
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
"statements": [
{
"statement": "Calpurnia urges Caesar to stay home.",
"reason": "The context explicitly states that Calphurnia says 'Do not go forth today. Call it my fear / That keeps you in the house, and not your own.'",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia's fear is the reason she urges Caesar to stay home.",
"reason": "The context states that Calphurnia says 'Do not go forth today. Call it my fear / That keeps you in the house, and not your own.' This implies that her fear is the reason she urges Caesar to stay home.",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia's fear is due to a bad dream or omen she had.",
"reason": "The context does not explicitly state that Calpurnia's fear is due to a bad dream or omen. It only mentions that she says 'Do not go forth today. Call it my fear / That keeps you in the house, and not your own.'",
"verdict": 0
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia's fear suggests that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate.",
"reason": "The context does not explicitly state that Calpurnia's fear suggests that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate. However, it can be inferred that her fear is related to Caesar's safety, as she says 'If thou beest not / immortal, look about you.'",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia asks Caesar to stay home due to her fear.",
"reason": "The context explicitly states that Calphurnia says 'Do not go forth today. Call it my fear / That keeps you in the house, and not your own.' This implies that she asks Caesar to stay home due to her fear.",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia does not want Caesar to make his own decision to go to the Senate.",
"reason": "The context does not explicitly state that Calpurnia does not want Caesar to make his own decision to go to the Senate. However, it can be inferred that she wants to influence his decision, as she offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well.",
"verdict": 0
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well.",
"reason": "The context explicitly states that Calphurnia says 'We’ll send Mark Antony to the Senate House, / And he shall say you are not well today.'",
"verdict": 1
},
{
"statement": "Calpurnia's offer is to avoid Caesar having to go to the Senate.",
"reason": "The context explicitly states that Calphurnia says 'We’ll send Mark Antony to the Senate House, / And he shall say you are not well today.' This implies that her offer is to avoid Caesar having to go to the Senate.",
"verdict": 1
}
]
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:28:49.495543
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Caesar first enters the play in Act 1, Scene 2, with a procession, accompanied by Antony, Calphurnia, Portia, Decius, Cicero, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, a Soothsayer, and others, including Marullus and Flavius and Commoners, as he is about to run a course, likely a triumphal procession, and is warned by a Soothsayer to \"Beware the Ides of March\"."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Where does Caesar first enter the play in?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:29:49.570970
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "Why does Caesar ignore Calpurnia's warnings?",
    "answer": "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings because he believes that as a powerful leader, he should not show fear or weakness. When Decius asks him to provide a reason for not attending the Senate, Caesar says \"The cause is in my will\" and earlier, he also states \"Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser\" and \"Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?\" This suggests that Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason, ultimately ignoring her warnings."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings.",
    "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings because he believes that as a powerful leader, he should not show fear or weakness.",
    "Caesar is asked by Decius to provide a reason for not attending the Senate.",
    "Caesar says that the cause is in his will.",
    "Caesar says that cannot is false.",
    "Caesar says that he dares not is false.",
    "Caesar says that he should not send a lie.",
    "Caesar says that he has stretched his arm so far in conquest.",
    "Caesar says that he is afraid to tell graybeards the truth.",
    "Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns.",
    "Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Decius's request for a reason.",
    "Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to ignore Calpurnia's warnings."
  ]
}

===============================================
TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:29:53.152663
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {

--------EXAMPLES-----------

    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. }

        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

He also delivers a eulogy, praising Caesar and criticizing the conspirators who killed him. Later, he asks a servant to post back with speed to tell Octavius about Caesar's death and the state of Rome, and he prepares to carry Caesar's body to the marketplace to deliver a speech to the people."

MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "115\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 2\nANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nThey exit with Caesar’s body. PLEBEIANS\nBRUTUS\n And bid me say to you by word of mouth—\n O Caesar! Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for  mine eyes,\n Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,\n Began to water. Is thy master coming? He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. Post back with speed and tell him what hath\n chanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,\n No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;\n Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse\n Into the marketplace. There shall I try,\n In my oration, how the people take\n The cruel issue of these bloody men,\n According to the which thou shalt discourse\n To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians. We will be satisfied!\n83\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\n What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\n Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\n Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy\n As that same ague which hath made you lean.—\n What is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\n Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\n109\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\n Either a coward or a flatterer.—\n That I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\n Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\n To see thy Antony making his peace,\n Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\n Most noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\n Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\n It would become me better than to close\n In terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\n hart,\n Here didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\n Signed in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\n And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\n Dost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\n  \n Pardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\n Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\n Or shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\n Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\n Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\n Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.",
    "statements": [
        "Antony arrives at Caesar's body.",
        "Antony weeps and mourns at Caesar's body.",
        "Antony shows his grief and loyalty to Caesar.",
        "Antony says that if he had as many eyes as Caesar has wounds, he would weep as fast as they stream forth Caesar's blood.",

        "Antony praises Caesar.",

    ]
}

MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings because he believes that as a powerful leader, he should not show fear or weakness. When Decius asks him to provide a reason for not attending the Senate, Caesar says \"The cause is in my will\" and earlier, he also states \"Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser\" and \"Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?\" This suggests that Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason, ultimately ignoring her warnings."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Why does Caesar ignore Calpurnia's warnings?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {

He says that if he had as many eyes as Caesar has wounds, he would weep as fast as they stream forth Caesar's blood. He also delivers a eulogy, praising Caesar and criticizing the conspirators who killed him. Later, he asks a servant to post back with speed to tell Octavius about Caesar's death and the state of Rome, and he prepares to carry Caesar's body to the marketplace to deliver a speech to the people."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "What happens when Antony arrives at Caesar's body?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

However, according to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first, but the provided excerpt starts with Antony's speech. \n\nSo, according to the play: Brutus\nAccording to the given context: Antony"
}

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

His funerals shall not be in our camp,\n Lest it discomfort us.—Lucilius, come.—\n And come, young Cato. I remember\n The first time ever Caesar put it on. ’Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent,\n That day he overcame the Nervii. Look, in this place ran Cassius’ dagger through. See what a rent the envious Casca made. Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed,\n And, as he plucked his cursèd steel away,\n Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it,\n As rushing out of doors to be resolved\n If Brutus so unkindly knocked or no;\n For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel. Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him! This was the most unkindest cut of all. For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,\n Ingratitude, more strong than traitors’ arms,\n Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart,\n And, in his mantle muffling up his face,\n Even at the base of Pompey’s statue\n (Which all the while ran blood) great Caesar fell. O, what a fall was there, my countrymen! Then I and you and all of us fell down,\n Whilst bloody treason flourished over us. O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel\n The dint of pity. These are gracious drops. Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold\n Our Caesar’s vesture wounded? Look you here,\n Here is himself, marred as you see with traitors. O piteous spectacle! Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

They mean to warn us at Philippi here,\n Answering before we do demand of them. Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know\n Wherefore they do it. They could be content\n To visit other places, and come down\n With fearful bravery, thinking by this face\n To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage. And died so?\n143\nJulius Caesar\nACT 4. SC. 1\nOCTAVIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nANTONY\n  \n So you thought him\n And took his voice who should be pricked to die\n In our black sentence and proscription. Octavius, I have seen more days than you,\n And, though we lay these honors on this man\n To ease ourselves of diverse sland’rous loads,\n He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,\n To groan and sweat under the business,\n Either led or driven, as we point the way;\n And having brought our treasure where we will,\n Then take we down his load and turn him off\n (Like to the empty ass) to shake his ears\n And graze in commons. You may do your will,\n But he’s a tried and valiant soldier. So is my horse, Octavius, and for that\n I do appoint him store of provender. It is a creature that I teach to fight,\n To wind, to stop, to run directly on,\n His corporal motion governed by my spirit;\n And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so. He must be taught and trained and bid go forth—\n A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds\n On objects, arts, and imitations\n Which, out of use and staled by other men,\n Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him\n But as a property. And now, Octavius,\n Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius\n Are levying powers. We must straight make head.\nHow now, fellow? Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome. Where is he? He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house. And thither will I straight to visit him. He comes upon a wish. PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
