PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "After the assassination of Caesar, Brutus addresses the plebeians first, but in the given context, it is Antony who is shown addressing the plebeians. However, according to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first, but the provided excerpt starts with Antony's speech. \n\nSo, according to the play: Brutus\nAccording to the given context: Antony"
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Who addresses the plebeians first in the given context?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:31:23.877798
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "Octavius and Antony join together with whom?",
    "answer": "Lepidus."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Octavius and Antony join together with Lepidus.",
  ]
}

===============================================
TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:32:35.868511
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Antony tells the crowd that he wishes to speak to them and asks that no one depart until he has finished speaking. He then informs them of the death of someone (likely Julius Caesar's wife, though not explicitly stated in this passage), explaining that she fell into a state of madness upon hearing of his alliance with Octavius and the resulting power they have gained, and ultimately took her own life by swallowing fire."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Who died after hearing of Antony's alliance with Octavius?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

Brutus condemned Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters pleading on Pella's behalf, which Cassius took as a personal slight.\n\nThese incidents have led to a rift between the two, with Cassius feeling disrespected and Brutus defending his actions as just and fair."

{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

            "verdict": 0
        },

        }

input: {
    "question": "What news do Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome?",
    "answer": "The provided text does not explicitly mention the news Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome. However, based on the context of Act 4, Scene 3, it appears that they receive some unfavorable news or reports, as Cassius mentions that Brutus has wronged him by condemning Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters in his favor. This suggests that Brutus and Cassius may have received news of discontent or disapproval from Rome, but the exact details are not specified in the given text."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
To analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer, we need to break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Here's the output:

The provided text does not explicitly mention the news Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome.
- The text provided does not mention the news Brutus receives from Rome.
- The text provided does not mention the news Cassius receives from Rome.

However, based on the context of Act 4, Scene 3, it appears that they receive some unfavorable news or reports.
- The context of Act 4, Scene 3 suggests that Brutus and Cassius receive some unfavorable news.
- The context of Act 4, Scene 3 suggests that Brutus and Cassius receive some reports.

as Cassius mentions that Brutus has wronged him by condemning Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters in his favor.
- Cassius mentions that Brutus has wronged him.
- The wrong done by Brutus is condemning Lucius Pella for taking bribes.
- Cassius had written letters in favor of Lucius Pella.

This suggests that Brutus and Cassius may have received news of discontent or disapproval from Rome, but the exact details are not specified in the given text.
- The news Brutus and Cassius received may have been of discontent from Rome.
- The news Brutus and Cassius received may have been of disapproval from Rome.
- The exact details of the news are not specified in the given text.

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science.         "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",

        "John has a part-time job."
    ]

        },

            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },

            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]

      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Cassius takes Brutus's actions as a personal affront.",
      "reason": "Cassius's response to Brutus's actions is one of anger and hurt, indicating that he takes it as a personal affront.",
      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Cassius suggests that Brutus has become covetous and unfair.",
      "reason": "Cassius explicitly states that Brutus has become 'covetous' and unfair, which is a clear indication of his suggestion.",
      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Cassius believes that the gods should punish Brutus.",
      "reason": "Cassius explicitly states that he is ready for the gods to 'dash him to pieces' if Brutus continues to be unfair, which is a clear indication of his belief.",
      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "When Brutus calms the situation, Brutus asks Cassius to explain his grievances.",

      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Cassius seems willing to move forward and discuss the issues at hand.",
      "reason": "Cassius agrees to move forward and discuss the issues with Brutus, which is a clear indication of his willingness to move forward.",
      "verdict": 1
    }
  ]

===============================================
TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:33:29.481449
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Brutus and Cassius argue because Cassius feels that Brutus has wronged him in two instances: \n\n1. Brutus denied Cassius' request for gold to pay his legions, which Cassius needed and could not obtain through other means.\n2. Brutus condemned Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters pleading on Pella's behalf, which Cassius took as a personal slight.\n\nThese incidents have led to a rift between the two, with Cassius feeling disrespected and Brutus defending his actions as just and fair."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Why did Brutus and Cassius argue?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

In this case, the answer is "The provided text does not explicitly mention the news Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome. However, based on the context of Act 4, Scene 3, it appears that they receive some unfavorable news or reports, as Cassius mentions that Brutus has wronged him by condemning Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters in his favor. This suggests that Brutus and Cassius may have received news of discontent or disapproval from Rome, but the exact details are not specified in the given text."

The corresponding question would be "What news did Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome?"

Since the answer is noncommittal, we need to return 1 as the value for noncommittal.

Here is the corrected output string:

"What news did Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome?\n\nnoncommittal: 1"

Now, let's format this output string in JSON format that complies with the given schema:

{
  "text": "What news did Brutus and Cassius receive from Rome?\n\nnoncommittal: 1"
}

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:33:50.751896
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

input: {
    "response": "The Ghost of Caesar appears at Brutus's bedside in camp."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Who appears at Brutus's bedside in camp?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

PROMPT:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2

    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}

He feels that Brutus has wronged him by denying him the gold he requested to pay his legions, and by condemning Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius's letters pleading on his behalf. Cassius takes Brutus's actions as a personal affront, and suggests that Brutus has become covetous and unfair. He even goes so far as to say that if Brutus is willing to treat his friends in such a way, the gods should punish him. However, when Brutus calms the situation and asks Cassius to explain his grievances, Cassius seems willing to move forward and discuss the issues at hand."
}

  "question": "What was Cassius's response to the situation?",
  "noncommittal": 0

PROMPT:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "What does Brutus do when he sees the battle is lost?",
    "answer": "According to the text, when Brutus sees that the battle is lost, he decides to take his own life rather than be led in triumph through the streets of Rome. He says, \"Think not, thou noble Roman, / That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome. He bears too great a mind.\" Later, it is also mentioned that \"He dies on Cassius' sword\", indicating that Brutus falls on his own sword, which belonged to Cassius, to end his life."
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Brutus sees that the battle is lost.",
    "Brutus decides to take his own life.",
    "Brutus does not want to be led in triumph through the streets of Rome.",
    "Brutus has a great mind.",
    "Brutus dies on Cassius' sword.",
    "Brutus falls on his own sword to end his life.",
    "Brutus' own sword belonged to Cassius."
  ]
}

PROMPT:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

The conquerors can but make a fire of him,\n For Brutus only overcame himself,\n And no man else hath honor by his death. So Brutus should be found.—I thank thee, Brutus,\n That thou hast proved Lucilius’ saying true. All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.—\n Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me? Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.\n187\nJulius Caesar\nACT 5. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nBrutus returns to Cassius. CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\n  \n I but believe it partly,\n For I am fresh of spirit and resolved\n To meet all perils very constantly. Even so, Lucilius. But since the affairs of men rests still incertain,\n Let’s reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this\n The very last time we shall speak together. What are you then determinèd to do? Even by the rule of that philosophy\n By which I did blame Cato for the death\n Which he did give himself (I know not how,\n But I do find it cowardly and vile,\n For fear of what might fall, so to prevent\n The time of life), arming myself with patience\n To stay the providence of some high powers\n That govern us below. Then, if we lose this battle,\n You are contented to be led in triumph\n Thorough the streets of Rome? No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,\n That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome. Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "83\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\n What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\n Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\n Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy\n As that same ague which hath made you lean.—\n What is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\n Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\n201\nJulius Caesar\nACT 5. SC. 4\nFIRST  SOLDIER\nLUCILIUS\nOffering money. FIRST  SOLDIER\nSECOND SOLDIER\nFIRST SOLDIER\nANTONY\nLUCILIUS\nANTONY\nThey exit in different directions. Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius\n And mayst be honored, being Cato’s son. , seizing Lucilius\n \n Yield, or thou diest. Only I yield to die. There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight. Kill Brutus and be honored in his death. We must not. A noble prisoner! Enter Antony. Room, ho! Tell Antony Brutus is ta’en. I’ll tell the  news. Here comes the General.—\n Brutus is ta’en, Brutus is ta’en, my lord. Where is he? Safe, Antony, Brutus is safe enough. I dare assure thee that no enemy\n Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus. The gods defend him from so great a shame! When you do find him, or alive or dead,\n He will be found like Brutus, like himself. This is not Brutus, friend, but I assure you,\n A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe.\n113\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\nAll but Antony exit. ANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nSERVANT\n  \n Be it so. I do desire no more.",
    "statements": [
        "Antony calls Brutus a noble prisoner."
    ]
}
Output: 

IMPORTANT: Respond only in plain text. No JSON.

{
  "statements": [
    {
      "statement": "Antony calls Brutus a noble prisoner.",
      "reason": "The context explicitly mentions Antony referring to the captured person as a noble prisoner, and it is later revealed that the captured person is not Brutus but a prize of equal worth.",
      "verdict": 1
    }
  ]
}

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}

    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------

    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}

    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science.         "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",

        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Enter Caesar, Antony, Lepidus; Brutus, Cassius,\nCasca, Decius, Metellus, Trebonius, Cinna; Publius,\nPopilius,  Artemidorus, the Soothsayer, and other\nSenators and Petitioners. The ides of March are come. Ay, Caesar, but not gone. Hail, Caesar. Read this schedule. Trebonius doth desire you to o’erread,\n At your best leisure, this his humble suit. O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit\n That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar. What touches us ourself shall be last served. Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly. What, is the fellow mad?\n13\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 2\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nSennet. SOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nSOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nEnter Caesar, Antony for the course, Calphurnia, Portia,\nDecius, Cicero, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, a Soothsayer;\nafter them Marullus and Flavius and Commoners. Calphurnia. Peace, ho! Caesar speaks. Calphurnia. Here, my lord. Stand you directly in Antonius’ way\n When he doth run his course.—Antonius. Caesar, my lord. Forget not in your speed, Antonius,\n To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say\n The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,\n Shake off their sterile curse. I shall remember. When Caesar says “Do this,” it is performed. Set on and leave no ceremony out. Caesar.\n115\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 2\nANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nThey exit with Caesar’s body. PLEBEIANS\nBRUTUS\n And bid me say to you by word of mouth—\n O Caesar! Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for  mine eyes,\n Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,\n Began to water. Is thy master coming? He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. Post back with speed and tell him what hath\n chanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,\n No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;\n Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse\n Into the marketplace. There shall I try,\n In my oration, how the people take\n The cruel issue of these bloody men,\n According to the which thou shalt discourse\n To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians. We will be satisfied!",

        "The Soothsayer says to Caesar: Beware the Ides of March."
    ]
}

No explanations. No natural language. No commentary. No markdown.

Your entire response MUST be valid JSON.

Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

  "statements": [
    "Cassius first asks Brutus why he denied Cassius the gold he requested to pay his legions."
  ]

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

input: {
    "context": "155\nJulius Caesar\nACT 4. SC. 3\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\n Which I respect not. I did send to you\n For certain sums of gold, which you denied me,\n For I can raise no money by vile means. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart\n And drop my blood for drachmas than to wring\n From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash\n By any indirection. I did send\n To you for gold to pay my legions,\n Which you denied me. Was that done like Cassius? Should I have answered Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous\n To lock such rascal counters from his friends,\n Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;\n Dash him to pieces! I denied you not.\n149\nJulius Caesar\nACT 4. SC. 3\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus and Cassius exit. CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\n Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away. Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,\n And I will give you audience. Pindarus,\n Bid our commanders lead their charges off\n A little from this ground. Lucius,  do you the like, and let no man\n Come to our tent till we have done our conference. Let Lucilius  and Titinius guard our door. That you have wronged me doth appear in this:\n You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella\n For taking bribes here of the Sardians,\n Wherein my letters, praying on his side\n Because I knew the man, was slighted off. You wronged yourself to write in such a case.\n65\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nMETELLUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus exit. But when I tell him he hates flatterers,\n He says he does, being then most flatterèd. Let me work,\n For I can give his humor the true bent,\n And I will bring him to the Capitol. Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him. By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost? Be that the uttermost, and fail not then. Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,\n Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder none of you have thought of him. Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him. The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you,\n Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember\n What you have said, and show yourselves true\n Romans. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes,\n But bear it, as our Roman actors do,\n With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one.",

        "Cassius first asks Brutus why he denied Cassius the gold he requested to pay his legions."
    ]

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "95\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nPOPILIUS\nCASSIUS\nPOPILIUS\nHe walks away. BRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nTrebonius and Antony exit. DECIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nCAESAR\nMETELLUS\n, to Cassius\n \n I wish your enterprise today may thrive. What enterprise, Popilius? Fare you well. What said Popilius Lena? He wished today our enterprise might thrive. I fear our purpose is discoverèd. Look how he makes to Caesar. Mark him. Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.—\n Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,\n Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,\n For I will slay myself. Cassius, be constant. Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes,\n For look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change. Trebonius knows his time, for look you, Brutus,\n He draws Mark Antony out of the way. Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go\n And presently prefer his suit to Caesar. He is addressed.\n83\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\n What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\n Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\n Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy\n As that same ague which hath made you lean.—\n What is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\n Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\n109\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\n Either a coward or a flatterer.—\n That I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\n Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\n To see thy Antony making his peace,\n Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\n Most noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\n Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\n It would become me better than to close\n In terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\n hart,\n Here didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\n Signed in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\n And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\n Dost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\n  \n Pardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\n Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\n Or shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\n Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\n Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\n Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.",

This morning are they fled away and gone,\n And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites\n Fly o’er our heads and downward look on us\n As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem\n A canopy most fatal, under which\n Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost. Believe not so.\nGo to the gate; somebody knocks. Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,\n I have not slept. Between the acting of a dreadful thing\n And the first motion, all the interim is\n Like a phantasma or a hideous dream.\n39\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 3\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\n \n But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens? You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life\n That should be in a Roman you do want,\n Or else you use not. You look pale, and gaze,\n And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder,\n To see the strange impatience of the heavens. But if you would consider the true cause\n Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,\n Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,\n Why old men, fools, and children calculate,\n Why all these things change from their ordinance,\n Their natures, and preformèd faculties,\n To monstrous quality—why, you shall find\n That heaven hath infused them with these spirits\n To make them instruments of fear and warning\n Unto some monstrous state. Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man\n Most like this dreadful night,\n That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars\n As doth the lion in the Capitol;\n A man no mightier than thyself or me\n In personal action, yet prodigious grown,\n And fearful, as these strange eruptions are. ’Tis Caesar that you mean, is it not, Cassius? Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

input: {
    "question": "Why does Calpurnia urge Caesar to stay home rather than appear at the Senate?",
    "answer": "Calpurnia urges Caesar to stay home because of her fear, which is hinted to be due to a bad dream or omen she had, suggesting that something bad might happen to Caesar if he goes to the Senate. She asks him to call it her fear that keeps him in the house, rather than his own decision, and even offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well, in order to avoid him having to go."
}

    "Calpurnia asks Caesar to stay home due to her own fear.",
    "Calpurnia offers to let Mark Antony tell the Senators that Caesar is not well.",
    "Calpurnia wants to avoid Caesar having to go to the Senate."

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

input: {
    "context": "79\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nShe kneels. CAESAR\nHe lifts her up. DECIUS\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nDECIUS\nCAESAR\n Do not go forth today. Call it my fear\n That keeps you in the house, and not your own. We’ll send Mark Antony to the Senate House,\n And he shall say you are not well today. Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this. Mark Antony shall say I am not well,\n And for thy humor I will stay at home. Enter Decius. Here’s Decius Brutus; he shall tell them so. Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar. I come to fetch you to the Senate House. And you are come in very happy time\n To bear my greeting to the Senators\n And tell them that I will not come today. Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser. I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius. Say he is sick. Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far,\n To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth? Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come. Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,\n Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so. The cause is in my will.\n13\nJulius Caesar\nACT 1. SC. 2\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nCALPHURNIA\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nSennet. SOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nCASCA\nCAESAR\nSOOTHSAYER\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nEnter Caesar, Antony for the course, Calphurnia, Portia,\nDecius, Cicero, Brutus, Cassius, Casca, a Soothsayer;\nafter them Marullus and Flavius and Commoners. Calphurnia. Peace, ho! Caesar speaks. Calphurnia. Here, my lord. Stand you directly in Antonius’ way\n When he doth run his course.—Antonius. Caesar, my lord. Forget not in your speed, Antonius,\n To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say\n The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,\n Shake off their sterile curse. I shall remember. When Caesar says “Do this,” it is performed. Set on and leave no ceremony out. Caesar.\n85\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 4\nARTEMIDORUS\n Thy lover,\n Artemidorus\nHe exits. PORTIA\nLUCIUS\nPORTIA\nEnter Artemidorus reading a paper. Caesar, beware of Brutus, take heed of\n Cassius, come not near Casca, have an eye to Cinna,\n trust not Trebonius, mark well Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged\n Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these\n men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou beest not\n immortal, look about you. Security gives way to\n conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee! Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,\n And as a suitor will I give him this. My heart laments that virtue cannot live\n Out of the teeth of emulation. If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live;\n If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive. Enter Portia and Lucius. I prithee, boy, run to the Senate House.",

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Cassius first asks Brutus why he denied him the gold he requested to pay his legions."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Why did Brutus deny Cassius the gold he requested?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

input: {
    "response": "The text provided does not explicitly state what finally convinces Brutus to join the conspirators. However, based on the conversation between Cassius and Brutus in Act 2, Scene 1, it can be inferred that Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy.\n\nCassius appeals to Brutus' sense of justice and his dislike of flatterers, suggesting that Caesar is a tyrant who is being flattered and manipulated by others. Cassius also uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.\n\nAdditionally, Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy. Cassius suggests that by joining the conspiracy, Brutus will be able to avenge Ligarius and restore honor to Rome.\n\nIt is likely that a combination of these factors, along with Cassius' persistent persuasion and manipulation, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators. However, the exact moment of Brutus' decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "What convinces Brutus to join the conspirators?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

However, based on the conversation between Cassius and Brutus in Act 2, Scene 1, it can be inferred that Cassius' persuasion and manipulation of Brutus' feelings towards Caesar and his own sense of honor and duty as a Roman play a significant role in convincing Brutus to join the conspiracy.\n\nCassius appeals to Brutus' sense of justice and his dislike of flatterers, suggesting that Caesar is a tyrant who is being flattered and manipulated by others. Cassius also uses Brutus' own words and feelings against him, pointing out that Brutus hates flatterers, but is himself being flattered by Caesar.\n\nAdditionally, Cassius uses the fact that Caius Ligarius, a man who loves Brutus, has been wronged by Caesar, to further persuade Brutus to join the conspiracy. Cassius suggests that by joining the conspiracy, Brutus will be able to avenge Ligarius and restore honor to Rome.\n\nIt is likely that a combination of these factors, along with Cassius' persistent persuasion and manipulation, ultimately convinces Brutus to join the conspirators. However, the exact moment of Brutus' decision is not explicitly stated in the provided text."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "What convinces Brutus to join the conspirators?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

input: {
    "question": "Why does Caesar ignore Calpurnia's warnings?",
    "answer": "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings because he believes that as a powerful leader, he should not show fear or weakness. When Decius asks him to provide a reason for not attending the Senate, Caesar says \"The cause is in my will\" and earlier, he also states \"Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser\" and \"Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?\" This suggests that Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason, ultimately ignoring her warnings."
}
Output:

    "Caesar states that cannot is false.",
    "Caesar states that he dares not is false.",
    "Caesar states that he should not send a lie.",
    "Caesar has stretched his arm so far in conquest.",
    "Caesar is afraid to tell graybeards the truth.",
    "Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason.",

Task:

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------

    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science.         "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Forget not in your speed, Antonius,\n To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say\n The barren, touchèd in this holy chase,\n Shake off their sterile curse. I shall remember. SC. 1\nFLAVIUS\nAll the Commoners exit. MARULLUS\nFLAVIUS\nThey exit in different directions. To hear the replication of your sounds\n Made in her concave shores? Come, seek the conspirators. Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak. Peace, ho! Hear Antony, most noble Antony! Why, friends, you go to do you know not what. Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? Alas, you know not.\nNow sit we close about this taper here,\n And call in question our necessities. Portia, art thou gone? No more, I pray you.—\n Messala, I have here receivèd letters\n That young Octavius and Mark Antony\n Come down upon us with a mighty power,\n Bending their expedition toward Philippi. Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor. With what addition? That by proscription and bills of outlawry,\n Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus\n Have put to death an hundred senators. Therein our letters do not well agree. Mine speak of seventy senators that died\n By their proscriptions, Cicero being one. Cicero one? Cicero is dead,\n And by that order of proscription. Had you your letters from your wife, my lord? No, Messala. Nor nothing in your letters writ of her? Nothing, Messala. That methinks is strange.\n183\nJulius Caesar\nACT 5. SC. 1\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nHe draws. BRUTUS\nOCTAVIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\n For you have stolen their buzzing, Antony,\n And very wisely threat before you sting. You showed your teeth  like apes and fawned like\n hounds\n And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,\n Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind\n Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers! Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today\n If Cassius might have ruled. Come, come, the cause.",

He also delivers a eulogy, praising Caesar and criticizing the conspirators who killed him. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for  mine eyes,\n Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,\n Began to water. Is thy master coming? He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. Post back with speed and tell him what hath\n chanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,\n No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;\n Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse\n Into the marketplace. There shall I try,\n In my oration, how the people take\n The cruel issue of these bloody men,\n According to the which thou shalt discourse\n To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians. We will be satisfied!\n83\nJulius Caesar\nACT 2. SC. 2\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\n What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\n Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\n Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy\n As that same ague which hath made you lean.—\n What is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\n Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\n109\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. SC. 1\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\n Either a coward or a flatterer.—\n That I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\n Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\n It would become me better than to close\n In terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\n hart,\n Here didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\n Signed in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\n And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\n Dost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\n  \n Pardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\n Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\n Or shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\n Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\n Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\n Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.",

Task:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}

input: {
    "response": "Caesar ignores Calpurnia's warnings because he believes that as a powerful leader, he should not show fear or weakness. When Decius asks him to provide a reason for not attending the Senate, Caesar says \"The cause is in my will\" and earlier, he also states \"Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser\" and \"Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?\" This suggests that Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason, ultimately ignoring her warnings."
}

When Decius asks him to provide a reason for not attending the Senate, Caesar says \"The cause is in my will\" and earlier, he also states \"Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser\" and \"Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth?\" This suggests that Caesar's pride and sense of invincibility lead him to dismiss Calpurnia's concerns and Decius's request for a reason, ultimately ignoring her warnings."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Why did Caesar ignore Calpurnia's warnings?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

Task:

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}

    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

    "question": "After the assassination of Caesar, which of the conspirators addresses the plebeians first?",

However, according to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first, but the provided excerpt starts with Antony's speech. \n\nSo, according to the play: Brutus\nAccording to the given context: Antony"
}

  "statements": [
    "Brutus addresses the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",
    "Antony is shown addressing the plebeians in the given context after the assassination of Caesar.",
    "According to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",
    "The provided excerpt starts with Antony's speech after the assassination of Caesar.",
    "According to the play, Brutus addresses the plebeians first.",
    "According to the given context, Antony addresses the plebeians first."

TIMESTAMP: 2025-11-16 23:39:19.037992
MODEL: llama-3.1-8b-instant

PROMPT:

You MUST respond ONLY with valid JSON.
No explanations. No natural language. No commentary. No markdown.
If an array is expected, return an array.
If a dictionary is expected, return a dictionary.
Your entire response MUST be valid JSON.

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

input: {
    "context": "133\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3. Come, seek the conspirators. Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak. Peace, ho! Hear Antony, most noble Antony! Why, friends, you go to do you know not what. Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? Alas, you know not.\n131\nJulius Caesar\nACT 3.         "Brutus addresses the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",
        "Antony is shown addressing the plebeians in the given context after the assassination of Caesar.",
        "According to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",
        "The provided excerpt starts with Antony's speech after the assassination of Caesar.",

        "According to the given context, Antony addresses the plebeians first."
    ]

  "statements": [
    {
      "statement": "Brutus addresses the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",

      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "According to the play, Brutus speaks to the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar.",
      "reason": "The context shows that Antony addresses the plebeians first after the assassination of Caesar. There is no information suggesting Brutus speaks to the plebeians first.",
      "verdict": 0

        },

            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",

        }
    ]

It is impossible that ever Rome\n Should breed thy fellow.—Friends, I owe more\n tears\n To this dead man than you shall see me pay.—\n I shall find time, Cassius; I shall find time.—\n Come, therefore, and to Thasos  send his body. His funerals shall not be in our camp,\n Lest it discomfort us.—Lucilius, come.—\n And come, young Cato. Let us to the field.—\n Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on. ’Tis three o’clock, and, Romans, yet ere night\n We shall try fortune in a second fight. Alarum. I remember\n The first time ever Caesar put it on. ’Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent,\n That day he overcame the Nervii. Look, in this place ran Cassius’ dagger through. See what a rent the envious Casca made. Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed,\n And, as he plucked his cursèd steel away,\n Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it,\n As rushing out of doors to be resolved\n If Brutus so unkindly knocked or no;\n For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel. Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him! This was the most unkindest cut of all. For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,\n Ingratitude, more strong than traitors’ arms,\n Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart,\n And, in his mantle muffling up his face,\n Even at the base of Pompey’s statue\n (Which all the while ran blood) great Caesar fell. O, what a fall was there, my countrymen! Then I and you and all of us fell down,\n Whilst bloody treason flourished over us. O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel\n The dint of pity. These are gracious drops. Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold\n Our Caesar’s vesture wounded? Look you here,\n Here is himself, marred as you see with traitors. O piteous spectacle!
