{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "ANTONY\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nOur reasons are so full of good regard\nThat were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,\nYou should be satisfied. That’s all I seek;\nAnd am, moreover, suitor that I may\nProduce his body to the marketplace,\nAnd in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,\nSpeak in the order of his funeral. You shall, Mark Antony. Brutus, a word with you. Aside to Brutus. You know not what you do. Do\nnot consent\nThat Antony speak in his funeral. Know you how much the people may be moved\nBy that which he will utter? , aside to Cassius\nBy your pardon,\nI will myself into the pulpit first\nAnd show the reason of our Caesar’s death. What Antony shall speak I will protest\nHe speaks by leave and by permission,\nAnd that we are contented Caesar shall\nHave all true rites and lawful ceremonies. It shall advantage more than do us wrong.\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\nEither a coward or a flatterer.—\nThat I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\nShall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\nTo see thy Antony making his peace,\nShaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\nMost noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\nWeeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\nIt would become me better than to close\nIn terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\nhart,\nHere didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\nSigned in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\nAnd this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\nDost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\nPardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\nThen, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\nOr shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\nSwayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\nUpon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\nWhy and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.\nOCTAVIUS\nANTONY\nMESSENGER\nANTONY\nEnter Octavius, Antony, and their army. Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd. You said the enemy would not come down\nBut keep the hills and upper regions. It proves not so; their battles are at hand. They mean to warn us at Philippi here,\nAnswering before we do demand of them. Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know\nWherefore they do it. They could be content\nTo visit other places, and come down\nWith fearful bravery, thinking by this face\nTo fasten in our thoughts that they have courage. But ’tis not so.",
    "statements": [
        "The crowd's response to Antony's speech is not explicitly stated.",
        "The given text does not provide information about the crowd's response to Antony's speech.",
        "Cassius is concerned about how the crowd may react to Antony's speech.",
        "Antony's words could move the people against them."
    ]
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "The crowd's response to Antony's speech is not explicitly stated.",
            "reason": "The context does not explicitly state the crowd's response to Antony's speech.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "The given text does not provide information about the crowd's response to Antony's speech.",
            "reason": "This statement is a repetition of the first statement and is therefore not directly inferred from the context.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "Cassius is concerned about how the crowd may react to Antony's speech.",
            "reason": "The context explicitly states that Cassius is concerned about how the crowd may be moved by Antony's speech.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "Antony's words could move the people against them.",
            "reason": "The context suggests that Antony's words could have a significant impact on the crowd, implying that they could be moved against the speakers.",
            "verdict": 1
        }
    ]
}

Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "MESSALA\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nThey all exit. Octavius, then take him to follow thee,\nThat did the latest service to my master. This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the conspirators save only he\nDid that they did in envy of great Caesar. He only in a general honest thought\nAnd common good to all made one of them. His life was gentle and the elements\nSo mixed in him that nature might stand up\nAnd say to all the world “This was a man.”\nAccording to his virtue, let us use him\nWith all respect and rites of burial. Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie,\nMost like a soldier, ordered honorably.\nOCTAVIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nANTONY\nSo you thought him\nAnd took his voice who should be pricked to die\nIn our black sentence and proscription. Octavius, I have seen more days than you,\nAnd, though we lay these honors on this man\nTo ease ourselves of diverse sland’rous loads,\nHe shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,\nTo groan and sweat under the business,\nEither led or driven, as we point the way;\nAnd having brought our treasure where we will,\nThen take we down his load and turn him off\n(Like to the empty ass) to shake his ears\nAnd graze in commons. You may do your will,\nBut he’s a tried and valiant soldier. So is my horse, Octavius, and for that\nI do appoint him store of provender. It is a creature that I teach to fight,\nTo wind, to stop, to run directly on,\nHis corporal motion governed by my spirit;\nAnd, in some taste, is Lepidus but so. He must be taught and trained and bid go forth—\nA barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds\nOn objects, arts, and imitations\nWhich, out of use and staled by other men,\nBegin his fashion. Do not talk of him\nBut as a property. And now, Octavius,\nListen great things. Brutus and Cassius\nAre levying powers. We must straight make head.\nUpon what sickness? Impatient of my absence,\nAnd grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony\nHave made themselves so strong—for with her\ndeath\nThat tidings came—with this she fell distract\nAnd, her attendants absent, swallowed fire. And died so?",
    "statements": [
        "Octavius is one of the main characters in the given context.",
        "Octavius is also known as Octavian.",
        "Octavian later became the Roman Emperor Augustus.",
        "Octavius is a leader.",
        "Octavius is a member of the Second Triumvirate.",
        "Octavius is along with Mark Antony and Lepidus.",
        "Octavius is shown to be a strong individual.",
        "Octavius is shown to be an ambitious individual.",
        "Octavius is willing to do what it takes to achieve his goals."
    ]
}

Task:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

input: {

}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "Why did Brutus kill Caesar?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "Octavius and Antony join together with whom?",
    "answer": "Lepidus and their army, then later with a messenger and Messala."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Octavius and Antony join together with Lepidus and their army.",
    "Octavius and Antony join together with a messenger.",
    "Octavius and Antony join together with Messala."
  ]
}

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "OCTAVIUS\nANTONY\nMESSENGER\nANTONY\nEnter Octavius, Antony, and their army. Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd. You said the enemy would not come down\nBut keep the hills and upper regions. It proves not so; their battles are at hand. They mean to warn us at Philippi here,\nAnswering before we do demand of them. Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know\nWherefore they do it. They could be content\nTo visit other places, and come down\nWith fearful bravery, thinking by this face\nTo fasten in our thoughts that they have courage. But ’tis not so.\nMESSALA\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nThey all exit. Octavius, then take him to follow thee,\nThat did the latest service to my master. This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the conspirators save only he\nDid that they did in envy of great Caesar. He only in a general honest thought\nAnd common good to all made one of them. His life was gentle and the elements\nSo mixed in him that nature might stand up\nAnd say to all the world “This was a man.”\nAccording to his virtue, let us use him\nWith all respect and rites of burial. Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie,\nMost like a soldier, ordered honorably.\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nLEPIDUS\nOCTAVIUS\nLEPIDUS\nANTONY\nLEPIDUS\nOCTAVIUS\nLepidus exits. ANTONY\nEnter Antony, Octavius, and Lepidus. These many, then, shall die; their names are\npricked. Your brother too must die. Consent you, Lepidus? I do consent. Prick him down, Antony. Upon condition Publius shall not live,\nWho is your sister’s son, Mark Antony. He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him. But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house;\nFetch the will hither, and we shall determine\nHow to cut off some charge in legacies. What, shall I find you here?",
    "statements": [
        "Octavius and Antony join together with Lepidus and their army.",
        "Octavius and Antony join together with a messenger.",
        "Octavius and Antony join together with Messala."
    ]
}
Output:

      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Octavius and Antony join together with a messenger.",
      "reason": "The context mentions a messenger, but it does not imply that the messenger joins Octavius and Antony.",
      "verdict": 0
    },
    {
      "statement": "Octavius and Antony join together with Messala.",
      "reason": "The context mentions Messala, but it does not imply that Messala joins Octavius and Antony.",
      "verdict": 0
    }
  ]

    "question": "Why do Brutus and Cassius argue?",
    "answer": "Brutus and Cassius argue because Brutus denied Cassius' request for gold to pay his legions, which Cassius believes was not done in a manner befitting their friendship. Cassius had sent to Brutus for certain sums of gold, but Brutus refused, claiming he could not raise money by vile means. Cassius takes this as a personal affront and feels that Brutus has wronged him. Additionally, Cassius is upset that Brutus has condemned and noted Lucius Pella for taking bribes, despite Cassius' letters pleading on Pella's behalf."

            "verdict": 1
        },

        }

I did send to you\nFor certain sums of gold, which you denied me,\nFor I can raise no money by vile means. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart\nAnd drop my blood for drachmas than to wring\nFrom the hard hands of peasants their vile trash\nBy any indirection. I did send\nTo you for gold to pay my legions,\nWhich you denied me. Was that done like Cassius? Should I have answered Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous\nTo lock such rascal counters from his friends,\nBe ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;\nDash him to pieces! I denied you not.\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nBrutus returns to Cassius. CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nI but believe it partly,\nFor I am fresh of spirit and resolved\nTo meet all perils very constantly. Even so, Lucilius. Now, most noble Brutus,\nThe gods today stand friendly that we may,\nLovers in peace, lead on our days to age. But since the affairs of men rests still incertain,\nLet’s reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this\nThe very last time we shall speak together. What are you then determinèd to do? Even by the rule of that philosophy\nBy which I did blame Cato for the death\nWhich he did give himself (I know not how,\nBut I do find it cowardly and vile,\nFor fear of what might fall, so to prevent\nThe time of life), arming myself with patience\nTo stay the providence of some high powers\nThat govern us below. Then, if we lose this battle,\nYou are contented to be led in triumph\nThorough the streets of Rome? No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,\nThat ever Brutus will go bound to Rome. Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCINNA\nMETELLUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nAll but Brutus exit. But when I tell him he hates flatterers,\nHe says he does, being then most flatterèd. Let me work,\nFor I can give his humor the true bent,\nAnd I will bring him to the Capitol. Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him. By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost? Be that the uttermost, and fail not then. Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,\nWho rated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder none of you have thought of him. Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him. The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you,\nBrutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember\nWhat you have said, and show yourselves true\nRomans. Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes,\nBut bear it, as our Roman actors do,\nWith untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one.\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nUnder these hard conditions as this time\nIs like to lay upon us. I am glad that my weak words\nHave struck but thus much show of fire from\nBrutus. Enter Caesar and his train. The games are done, and Caesar is returning. As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve,\nAnd he will, after his sour fashion, tell you\nWhat hath proceeded worthy note today. I will do so. But look you, Cassius,\nThe angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow,\nAnd all the rest look like a chidden train. Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero\nLooks with such ferret and such fiery eyes\nAs we have seen him in the Capitol,\nBeing crossed in conference by some senators. Casca will tell us what the matter is.\nPUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\nWhat, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\nGood morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\nCaesar was ne’er so much your enemy\nAs that same ague which hath made you lean.—\nWhat is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\nIs notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.",

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}

    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

LUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nEverything is well. Good night, my lord. Good night, good brother. Good night, Lord Brutus. Farewell, everyone. Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument? Here in the tent. What, thou speak’st drowsily? Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o’erwatched. Call Claudius and some other of my men;\nI’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent. Varro and Claudius. Enter Varro and Claudius. Calls my lord? I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep. It may be I shall raise you by and by\nOn business to my brother Cassius.             "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",

        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]

            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",

            "verdict": 0

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nWhich I respect not. I did send to you\nFor certain sums of gold, which you denied me,\nFor I can raise no money by vile means. By heaven, I had rather coin my heart\nAnd drop my blood for drachmas than to wring\nFrom the hard hands of peasants their vile trash\nBy any indirection. I did send\nTo you for gold to pay my legions,\nWhich you denied me. Was that done like Cassius? Should I have answered Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous\nTo lock such rascal counters from his friends,\nBe ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;\nDash him to pieces! I denied you not.\nGo to the gate; somebody knocks. Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,\nI have not slept. Between the acting of a dreadful thing\nAnd the first motion, all the interim is\nLike a phantasma or a hideous dream.\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nUnder these hard conditions as this time\nIs like to lay upon us. I am glad that my weak words\nHave struck but thus much show of fire from\nBrutus. Enter Caesar and his train. The games are done, and Caesar is returning. As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve,\nAnd he will, after his sour fashion, tell you\nWhat hath proceeded worthy note today. I will do so. But look you, Cassius,\nThe angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow,\nAnd all the rest look like a chidden train. Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero\nLooks with such ferret and such fiery eyes\nAs we have seen him in the Capitol,\nBeing crossed in conference by some senators. Casca will tell us what the matter is.",

        "Cassius is angry and offended that Brutus denied him the gold he requested.",

        "Cassius instructs one of his companions to speak with Casca.",

Task:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."

    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "response": "Cassius thinks that the friendship and loyalty between him and Brutus has begun to decay, using the metaphor of a hot horse cooling down, indicating a loss of passion and energy in their relationship, and that Brutus has become more concerned with money and material wealth, which Cassius believes is beneath them."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "question": "What is the metaphor used by Cassius to describe the decay of his friendship with Brutus?",
  "noncommittal": 0
}

Cassius feels that Brutus's refusal to provide him with the necessary funds is a personal betrayal, and he expresses his outrage and disappointment, suggesting that Brutus's behavior is unworthy of his reputation. He then shifts his attention to the approaching Caesar and his train, noting their somber mood and speculating about the cause of their displeasure. Cassius instructs one of his companions to speak with Casca and gather information about what has happened, indicating that he is interested in learning more about the situation and potentially using the information to further his own goals."
}

Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "What does Brutus do when he sees the battle is lost?",
    "answer": "Brutus runs on his sword, which means he kills himself by falling on the sword, rather than being taken captive and led in triumph through the streets of Rome."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Brutus runs on his sword.",
    "Brutus kills himself by falling on the sword.",
    "Brutus does not want to be taken captive.",
    "Brutus does not want to be led in triumph through the streets of Rome."
  ]
}

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nBrutus returns to Cassius. CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nI but believe it partly,\nFor I am fresh of spirit and resolved\nTo meet all perils very constantly. Even so, Lucilius. Now, most noble Brutus,\nThe gods today stand friendly that we may,\nLovers in peace, lead on our days to age. But since the affairs of men rests still incertain,\nLet’s reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this\nThe very last time we shall speak together. What are you then determinèd to do? Even by the rule of that philosophy\nBy which I did blame Cato for the death\nWhich he did give himself (I know not how,\nBut I do find it cowardly and vile,\nFor fear of what might fall, so to prevent\nThe time of life), arming myself with patience\nTo stay the providence of some high powers\nThat govern us below. Then, if we lose this battle,\nYou are contented to be led in triumph\nThorough the streets of Rome? No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman,\nThat ever Brutus will go bound to Rome. He bears too great a mind.\nRetreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Messala,\nLucilius, and the army. What man is that? My master’s man.—Strato, where is thy master? Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. The conquerors can but make a fire of him,\nFor Brutus only overcame himself,\nAnd no man else hath honor by his death. So Brutus should be found.—I thank thee, Brutus,\nThat thou hast proved Lucilius’ saying true. All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.—\nFellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me? Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.\nSTRATO\nBRUTUS\nBrutus runs on his sword. He dies. OCTAVIUS\nMESSALA\nSTRATO\nLUCILIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nSTRATO\nOCTAVIUS\nMESSALA\nSTRATO\nI prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord. Thou art a fellow of a good respect;\nThy life hath had some smatch of honor in it. Hold, then, my sword, and turn away thy face\nWhile I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato? Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord. Farewell, good Strato. Caesar, now be still. I killed not thee with half so good a will. Alarum.",
    "statements": [
        "Brutus runs on his sword.",
        "Brutus kills himself by falling on the sword.",
        "Brutus does not want to be taken captive.",
        "Brutus does not want to be led in triumph through the streets of Rome."
    ]
}

      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Brutus does not want to be taken captive.",
      "reason": "The context states that Brutus says he bears too great a mind to be taken captive.",
      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Brutus does not want to be led in triumph through the streets of Rome.",

input: {
    "context": "PUBLIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nCAESAR\nANTONY\nCAESAR\nServant exits. TREBONIUS\nCAESAR\nBRUTUS\nThey exit. Enter Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca, Trebonius,\nCinna, and Publius. And look where Publius is come to fetch me. Good morrow, Caesar. Welcome, Publius.—\nWhat, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?—\nGood morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius,\nCaesar was ne’er so much your enemy\nAs that same ague which hath made you lean.—\nWhat is ’t o’clock? Caesar, ’tis strucken eight. I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights\nIs notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony. So to most noble Caesar.\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\nAll but Antony exit. ANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nSERVANT\nBe it so. I do desire no more.\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nHe draws. BRUTUS\nOCTAVIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nFor you have stolen their buzzing, Antony,\nAnd very wisely threat before you sting. Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers\nHacked one another in the sides of Caesar. You showed your teeth like apes and fawned like\nhounds\nAnd bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,\nWhilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind\nStruck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers! Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today\nIf Cassius might have ruled. Come, come, the cause.",

        "Antony calls Brutus a flatterer."
    ]
}

{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "What physical weakness does Caesar reveal to Antony in Act 1, Scene 2?",
    "answer": "Caesar reveals that he is deaf in one ear, as he tells Antony to come on his right hand, for his left ear is deaf."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Caesar reveals that he is deaf in one ear.",
    "Caesar tells Antony to come on his right hand.",
    "Caesar's left ear is deaf."
  ]
}

No explanations. No natural language. No commentary. No markdown.
If an array is expected, return an array.
If a dictionary is expected, return a dictionary.
Your entire response MUST be valid JSON.

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a genius."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Albert Einstein was a genius.",
            "reason": "The context and statement are unrelated",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "CASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\nEither a coward or a flatterer.—\nThat I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\nShall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\nTo see thy Antony making his peace,\nShaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\nMost noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\nWeeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\nIt would become me better than to close\nIn terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\nhart,\nHere didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\nSigned in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\nAnd this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\nDost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\nPardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\nThen, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\nOr shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\nSwayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\nUpon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\nWhy and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nHe draws. BRUTUS\nOCTAVIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nFor you have stolen their buzzing, Antony,\nAnd very wisely threat before you sting. Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers\nHacked one another in the sides of Caesar. You showed your teeth like apes and fawned like\nhounds\nAnd bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,\nWhilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind\nStruck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers! Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today\nIf Cassius might have ruled. Come, come, the cause.\nSennet. Caesar and his train exit\nbut Casca remains behind. CASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nI do not know the man I should avoid\nSo soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much,\nHe is a great observer, and he looks\nQuite through the deeds of men. He loves no plays,\nAs thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;\nSeldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort\nAs if he mocked himself and scorned his spirit\nThat could be moved to smile at anything. Such men as he be never at heart’s ease\nWhiles they behold a greater than themselves,\nAnd therefore are they very dangerous. I rather tell thee what is to be feared\nThan what I fear; for always I am Caesar. Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,\nAnd tell me truly what thou think’st of him. You pulled me by the cloak. Would you speak\nwith me?",
    "statements": [
        "Caesar reveals that he is deaf in one ear.",
        "Caesar tells Antony to come on his right hand.",
        "Caesar's left ear is deaf."
    ]
}
Output:

    },
    {
      "statement": "Caesar tells Antony to come on his right hand.",
      "reason": "Caesar says to Brutus, Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf.",
      "verdict": 1
    },
    {
      "statement": "Caesar's left ear is deaf.",
      "reason": "Caesar says to Brutus, Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf.",
      "verdict": 1

    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",

input: {
    "question": "What does Antony's soliloquy over Caesar's body in Act 3, Scene 1 prophesy?",
    "answer": "Antony's soliloquy over Caesar's body in Act 3, Scene 1 prophesies that Caesar's death will lead to chaos and destruction in Rome, and that those responsible for his death, such as Brutus and Cassius, will ultimately face their own downfall. Antony's words, \"A curse shall light upon the limbs of men\" and \"Domestic fury and fierce civil strife\" will \"Shake the private cabins of Rome\", suggest that Caesar's death will unleash a wave of violence and disorder that will engulf the city, and that the conspirators will be brought to justice. This soliloquy marks a turning point in the play, as Antony's words set in motion the events that will lead to the downfall of the conspirators and the rise of the Second Triumvirate."
}
Output:

input: {
    "context": "ANTONY\nSERVANT\nANTONY\nThey exit with Caesar’s body. PLEBEIANS\nBRUTUS\nAnd bid me say to you by word of mouth—\nO Caesar! Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,\nSeeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,\nBegan to water. Is thy master coming? He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome. Post back with speed and tell him what hath\nchanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,\nNo Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile;\nThou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse\nInto the marketplace. There shall I try,\nIn my oration, how the people take\nThe cruel issue of these bloody men,\nAccording to the which thou shalt discourse\nTo young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. Enter Brutus and Cassius with the Plebeians. We will be satisfied!\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nBRUTUS\nEither a coward or a flatterer.—\nThat I did love thee, Caesar, O, ’tis true! If then thy spirit look upon us now,\nShall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death\nTo see thy Antony making his peace,\nShaking the bloody fingers of thy foes—\nMost noble!—in the presence of thy corpse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,\nWeeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,\nIt would become me better than to close\nIn terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bayed, brave\nhart,\nHere didst thou fall, and here thy hunters stand\nSigned in thy spoil and crimsoned in thy Lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart,\nAnd this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes\nDost thou here lie! Mark Antony—\nPardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this;\nThen, in a friend, it is cold modesty. I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends,\nOr shall we on and not depend on you? Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed\nSwayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all,\nUpon this hope, that you shall give me reasons\nWhy and wherein Caesar was dangerous. Or else were this a savage spectacle.\nSennet. Caesar and his train exit\nbut Casca remains behind. CASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nI do not know the man I should avoid\nSo soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much,\nHe is a great observer, and he looks\nQuite through the deeds of men. He loves no plays,\nAs thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;\nSeldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort\nAs if he mocked himself and scorned his spirit\nThat could be moved to smile at anything. Such men as he be never at heart’s ease\nWhiles they behold a greater than themselves,\nAnd therefore are they very dangerous. I rather tell thee what is to be feared\nThan what I fear; for always I am Caesar. Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,\nAnd tell me truly what thou think’st of him. You pulled me by the cloak. Would you speak\nwith me?",

        "The conspirators will be brought to justice.",
        "This soliloquy marks a turning point in the play.",
        "Antony's words set in motion the events that will lead to the downfall of the conspirators and the rise of the Second Triumvirate."
    ]
}
Output:

{
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "Caesar's death will lead to chaos and destruction in Rome.",
            "reason": "The context suggests that the death of Caesar will have significant consequences, and the mention of a mourning Rome and a dangerous Rome implies that chaos and destruction are likely outcomes.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "Those responsible for Caesar's death, such as Brutus and Cassius, will ultimately face their own downfall.",
            "reason": "The context implies that the conspirators will be held accountable for their actions, and Antony's words suggest that they will ultimately face the consequences of their actions.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "Caesar's death will unleash a wave of violence and disorder that will engulf the city.",

            "verdict": 1

            "statement": "This soliloquy marks a turning point in the play.",

            "verdict": 0
        }

PROMPT:

Task:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

Example 2
Input: {
    "response": "I don't know about the  groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023 as am unaware of information beyond 2022. "
}
Output: {
    "question": "What was the groundbreaking feature of the smartphone invented in 2023?",
    "noncommittal": 1
}
-----------------------------

  "question": "How does Brutus kill himself?",
  "noncommittal": 0

Task:

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",

Task:

Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science.         "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}

        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",

            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "CASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nHe drinks. CASSIUS\nHe drinks. Lucius exits. I did not think you could have been so angry. O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs. Of your philosophy you make no use\nIf you give place to accidental evils. No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead. Ha? Portia? She is dead. How ’scaped I killing when I crossed you so? O insupportable and touching loss!\nBRUTUS\nPORTIA\nBRUTUS\nKnock. Portia exits. LUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nLucius exits. LIGARIUS\nYou are my true and honorable wife,\nAs dear to me as are the ruddy drops\nThat visit my sad heart. If this were true, then should I know this secret. I grant I am a woman, but withal\nA woman that Lord Brutus took to wife. I grant I am a woman, but withal\nA woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter. Think you I am no stronger than my sex,\nBeing so fathered and so husbanded? Tell me your counsels; I will not disclose ’em. I have made strong proof of my constancy,\nGiving myself a voluntary wound\nHere, in the thigh. Can I bear that with patience,\nAnd not my husband’s secrets?\nBRUTUS\nPORTIA\nBRUTUS\nHe lifts her up. PORTIA\nWhy so I do. Good Portia, go to bed. Is Brutus sick? And is it physical\nTo walk unbracèd and suck up the humors\nOf the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,\nAnd will he steal out of his wholesome bed\nTo dare the vile contagion of the night\nAnd tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air\nTo add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus,\nYou have some sick offense within your mind,\nWhich by the right and virtue of my place\nI ought to know of. She kneels. And upon my\nknees\nI charm you, by my once commended beauty,\nBy all your vows of love, and that great vow\nWhich did incorporate and make us one,\nThat you unfold to me, your self, your half,\nWhy you are heavy, and what men tonight\nHave had resort to you; for here have been\nSome six or seven who did hide their faces\nEven from darkness. Kneel not, gentle Portia. I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus. Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,\nIs it excepted I should know no secrets\nThat appertain to you? Am I your self\nBut, as it were, in sort or limitation,\nTo keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,\nAnd talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the\nsuburbs\nOf your good pleasure?",

A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

The ghost of Caesar hath appeared to me\nTwo several times by night—at Sardis once\nAnd this last night here in Philippi fields. I know my hour is come.\nGHOST\nBRUTUS\nGHOST\nBRUTUS\nGHOST\nBRUTUS\nGhost exits. LUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nLUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nLUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nLUCIUS\nBRUTUS\nThey rise up. VARRO\nCLAUDIUS\nBRUTUS\nBOTH\nBRUTUS\nVARRO\nThy evil spirit, Brutus. Why com’st thou? To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi. Well, then I shall see thee again? Ay, at Philippi. Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then. Now I have taken heart, thou vanishest. Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.—\nBoy, Lucius!—Varro, Claudius, sirs, awake! Claudius! The strings, my lord, are false. He thinks he still is at his instrument. Lucius, awake! My lord? Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out? My lord, I do not know that I did cry. Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see anything? Nothing, my lord. Sleep again, Lucius.—Sirrah Claudius! To Varro. Fellow thou, awake! My lord? My lord? Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep? Did we, my lord?\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nBRUTUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nCASSIUS\nCASCA\nHe exits. What said he when he came unto himself? Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived\nthe common herd was glad he refused the crown,\nhe plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his\nthroat to cut. An I had been a man of any occupation,\nif I would not have taken him at a word, I\nwould I might go to hell among the rogues. And so\nhe fell. When he came to himself again, he said if he\nhad done or said anything amiss, he desired their\nWorships to think it was his infirmity. Three or four\nwenches where I stood cried “Alas, good soul!” and\nforgave him with all their hearts. But there’s no\nheed to be taken of them; if Caesar had stabbed\ntheir mothers, they would have done no less. And, after that, he came thus sad away? Ay. Did Cicero say anything? Ay, he spoke Greek. To what effect? Nay, an I tell you that, I’ll ne’er look you i’ th’\nface again. But those that understood him smiled at\none another and shook their heads. But for mine\nown part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more\nnews too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarves\noff Caesar’s images, are put to silence. Fare you\nwell.",

Your entire response MUST be valid JSON.

Task:
Generate a question for the given answer and Identify if answer is noncommittal. Give noncommittal as 1 if the answer is noncommittal and 0 if the answer is committal. A noncommittal answer is one that is evasive, vague, or ambiguous. For example, "I don't know" or "I'm not sure" are noncommittal answers
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"question": {"title": "Question", "type": "string"}, "noncommittal": {"title": "Noncommittal", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["question", "noncommittal"], "title": "ResponseRelevanceOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1

    "response": "Albert Einstein was born in Germany."
}
Output: {
    "question": "Where was Albert Einstein born?",
    "noncommittal": 0
}

    "noncommittal": 1
}

Task:
Given a question and an answer, analyze the complexity of each sentence in the answer. Break down each sentence into one or more fully understandable statements. Ensure that no pronouns are used in any statement. Format the outputs in JSON.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"properties": {"statements": {"description": "The generated statements", "items": {"type": "string"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "StatementGeneratorOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "question": "Who was Albert Einstein and what is he best known for?",
    "answer": "He was a German-born theoretical physicist, widely acknowledged to be one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time. He was best known for developing the theory of relativity, he also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        "Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist.",
        "Albert Einstein is recognized as one of the greatest and most influential physicists of all time.",
        "Albert Einstein was best known for developing the theory of relativity.",
        "Albert Einstein also made important contributions to the development of the theory of quantum mechanics."
    ]
}
-----------------------------

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "question": "In Act 2, Scene 1, what is Brutus's first major miscalculation regarding Mark Antony?",
    "answer": "Brutus's first major miscalculation regarding Mark Antony is allowing him to speak at Caesar's funeral, which Cassius warns against, knowing that Antony's words could stir up the people against them. Brutus underestimates the potential impact of Antony's speech and believes that by speaking first and explaining the reasons for Caesar's death, he can control the narrative and prevent Antony from doing harm. However, this decision ultimately proves to be a critical mistake, as Antony's speech goes on to sway the crowd against the conspirators."
}
Output: 


RESPONSE:
{
  "statements": [
    "Brutus's first major miscalculation regarding Mark Antony is allowing Mark Antony to speak at Caesar's funeral.",
    "Cassius warns Brutus against allowing Mark Antony to speak at Caesar's funeral.",
    "Mark Antony's words could stir up the people against Brutus and Cassius.",
    "Brutus underestimates the potential impact of Mark Antony's speech.",
    "Brutus believes that by speaking first and explaining the reasons for Caesar's death, he can control the narrative and prevent Mark Antony from doing harm.",
    "Brutus's decision to allow Mark Antony to speak at Caesar's funeral proves to be a critical mistake.",
    "Mark Antony's speech goes on to sway the crowd against Brutus and Cassius."
  ]

Task:
Your task is to judge the faithfulness of a series of statements based on a given context. For each statement you must return verdict as 1 if the statement can be directly inferred based on the context or 0 if the statement can not be directly inferred based on the context.
Please return the output in a JSON format that complies with the following schema as specified in JSON Schema:
{"$defs": {"StatementFaithfulnessAnswer": {"properties": {"statement": {"description": "the original statement, word-by-word", "title": "Statement", "type": "string"}, "reason": {"description": "the reason of the verdict", "title": "Reason", "type": "string"}, "verdict": {"description": "the verdict(0/1) of the faithfulness.", "title": "Verdict", "type": "integer"}}, "required": ["statement", "reason", "verdict"], "title": "StatementFaithfulnessAnswer", "type": "object"}}, "properties": {"statements": {"items": {"$ref": "#/$defs/StatementFaithfulnessAnswer"}, "title": "Statements", "type": "array"}}, "required": ["statements"], "title": "NLIStatementOutput", "type": "object"}Do not use single quotes in your response but double quotes,properly escaped with a backslash.

--------EXAMPLES-----------
Example 1
Input: {
    "context": "John is a student at XYZ University. He is pursuing a degree in Computer Science. He is enrolled in several courses this semester, including Data Structures, Algorithms, and Database Management. John is a diligent student and spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. He often stays late in the library to work on his projects.",
    "statements": [
        "John is majoring in Biology.",
        "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
        "John is a dedicated student.",
        "John has a part-time job."
    ]
}
Output: {
    "statements": [
        {
            "statement": "John is majoring in Biology.",
            "reason": "John's major is explicitly mentioned as Computer Science. There is no information suggesting he is majoring in Biology.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is taking a course on Artificial Intelligence.",
            "reason": "The context mentions the courses John is currently enrolled in, and Artificial Intelligence is not mentioned. Therefore, it cannot be deduced that John is taking a course on AI.",
            "verdict": 0
        },
        {
            "statement": "John is a dedicated student.",
            "reason": "The context states that he spends a significant amount of time studying and completing assignments. Additionally, it mentions that he often stays late in the library to work on his projects, which implies dedication.",
            "verdict": 1
        },
        {
            "statement": "John has a part-time job.",
            "reason": "There is no information given in the context about John having a part-time job.",
            "verdict": 0
        }
    ]
}

    "context": "Photosynthesis is a process used by plants, algae, and certain bacteria to convert light energy into chemical energy.",

    ]

Now perform the same with the following input
input: {
    "context": "ANTONY\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nBRUTUS\nOur reasons are so full of good regard\nThat were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,\nYou should be satisfied. That’s all I seek;\nAnd am, moreover, suitor that I may\nProduce his body to the marketplace,\nAnd in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,\nSpeak in the order of his funeral. You shall, Mark Antony. Brutus, a word with you. Aside to Brutus. You know not what you do. Do\nnot consent\nThat Antony speak in his funeral. Know you how much the people may be moved\nBy that which he will utter? , aside to Cassius\nBy your pardon,\nI will myself into the pulpit first\nAnd show the reason of our Caesar’s death. What Antony shall speak I will protest\nHe speaks by leave and by permission,\nAnd that we are contented Caesar shall\nHave all true rites and lawful ceremonies. It shall advantage more than do us wrong.\nPLEBEIANS\nFIRST PLEBEIAN\nSECOND PLEBEIAN\nTHIRD PLEBEIAN\nFOURTH PLEBEIAN\nFIRST PLEBEIAN\nBRUTUS\nSECOND PLEBEIAN\nFIRST PLEBEIAN\nBRUTUS\nmore to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The\nquestion of his death is enrolled in the Capitol, his\nglory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor\nhis offenses enforced for which he suffered death. Enter Mark Antony and others with Caesar’s body. Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony,\nwho, though he had no hand in his death, shall\nreceive the benefit of his dying—a place in the\ncommonwealth—as which of you shall not? With\nthis I depart: that, as I slew my best lover for the\ngood of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself\nwhen it shall please my country to need my death. Live, Brutus, live, live!\nANTONY\nCASSIUS\nOCTAVIUS\nHe draws. BRUTUS\nOCTAVIUS\nBRUTUS\nCASSIUS\nANTONY\nOCTAVIUS\nFor you have stolen their buzzing, Antony,\nAnd very wisely threat before you sting. Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers\nHacked one another in the sides of Caesar. You showed your teeth like apes and fawned like\nhounds\nAnd bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet,\nWhilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind\nStruck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers! Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today\nIf Cassius might have ruled. Come, come, the cause.",

    "answer": "Brutus makes the fatal mistake of allowing Mark Antony to speak at Caesar's funeral, which gives Antony the opportunity to turn the crowd against the conspirators and ultimately leads to their downfall. Brutus agrees to let Antony speak, despite Cassius' warning that Antony's words could move the people against them, and instead decides to speak first and explain the reasoning behind Caesar's death, believing that this will show the people that the conspirators acted with good intentions and that Caesar's death was justified.
